SYSTEMA AVIUM 
AUSTRALASIAN ARUM. 
A SYSTEMATIC LIST OF THE BIRDS OF 
THE AUSTRALASIAN REGION. 
BY 
GREGORY M. MATHEWS, F.R.S.E., M.BO.U. 
Prepared in conjunction with Special Committees of the 
British and American Ornithologists’ Unions. 
PUBLISHED BY THE 
BRITISH ORNITHOLOGISTS’ UNION 
AND SOLI) BY 
WHELDON AND WESLEY, LTD., 2-4 ARTHUR STREET, 
NEW OXFORD STREET, W.C. 2. 
1927. 

PRINTED BY TAYLOR ANI) FRANCIS. 
KKO LION COFRT, FLRKT STREET. 

/: 
■ /vW 
o V 
PREFACE. 
This volume embraces the Pacific Islands, from Easter Island to 
the Celebes. The line south of Celebes includes Lombok; north 
it runs east of the Philippines, also excluding the Bonin Islands; 
then east to include the Sandwich Islands ; south to Ross Sea[ 
Victoria Land, and King George V. Land—also the Islands of 
Amsterdam and St. Paul’s, in the Indian Ocean. 
The Classification followed is that of Sharpe’s ‘Hand-list.’ This 
is in conformity with the ‘ Chock-list of the Royal Australasian 
Ornithologists Union, the American Ornithologists’ Union, and 
my own works on Australia. 
The Nomenclature is founded on the Rules of the International 
Zoological Congress, except that our Committee agreed that 
names differing only in the endings -us,-a, um, -as, -os, -is, -es, -e, 
or -on wero to be considered identical. 
Galley-sheets have been distributed to many friends for correc¬ 
tion Drs. Hartert, Laubmann, Murphy, Phillips, Richmond, 
Riley, Stresemann, Wetmore ; Lord Rothschild, Professor New- 
maun, Mr. W. B. Alexander, and Mr. T. Wells. To all, my thanks 
are due. If amongst us we have omitted any quotation, we shall be 
obliged if someone will point it out for the “ List of Corrections.” 
I he absence of material has made the satisfactory working up 
of many species impossible. The same applies to the distribution, 
but this can be corrected by workers with more and better 
material. 
b 

IV 
PREFACE. 
The figure in brackets after the Latin name refers to the 
t Catalogue of Birds in the British Museum.’ I have also in 
many cases given the quotation where the bird is figured. 
The work was completed in 1925, but, as I remarked, galley- 
sheets were sent abroad ; therefore, the printing has been finished 
in sections—for example, pp. 1—112 were finally printed off in 
January 1926. This will explain the long list of corrections. 
The admission of genera is a matter of opinion. I have in some 
cases left the super-genera, as Phaethon. 
I have endeavoured to fix the type-locality of every quotation 
and the genotype of each genus. 
Foulis Court, Fair Oak, Hants. 
March 1927. 
GREGORY M. MATHEWS. 

PREFACE. 
In the Preface to Vol. I. I have said all that is necessary about 
the work. 
I have to thank my friends for the ever-ready help they have 
always given me. Proof-sheets were sent to Drs. Richmond, 
Wetmore, and Murphy, in America ; to Dr. Hartert and Mr. A. 
Goodson, of Tring Museum ; and Mr. T. Wells, of the British 
Museum ; Drs. Stresemann and Rensch, of Berlin. Mr. T. Wells 
also prepared the Index. I wish also to thank the authorities of 
the Natural History Museum in South Kensington, and Lord 
Rothschild of Tring Museum, for all the privileges I have 
enjoyed while compiling the 4 Systema. 5 
In the work I have admitted about 5030 forms, of which 
about 2280 are species; about 990 genera, of which 590 are 
monotypic. 
In a work in which about 9500 references have to be 
consulted, many several times, mistakes are bound to occur. 
I hope those who criticize will come under the heading of 
44 Constructive Critics,” so that we do not hear 44 the cracking of 
thorns under a pot ' 5 (Eccles. vii. 6). 
Towards the cost of the production of this Volume the 
following have subscribed, to whom the Committee of the British 
Ornithologists' Union wish to express their thanks :— 
Sir Samuel and Lady Hordern ; Rear-Admiral H. 
Lynes ; Messrs. W. A. Anderson, W. L. Baillieu, A. Ezra, 
C. B. Rickett, J. Delacour, A. W. Mathews, and Drs. 
Casey A. Wood, G. Carmichael Low, and Manson Bahr. 
In Opinions Rendered by the International Commission on 
Zoological Nomenclature (Opinions 98 to 104, Sept. 1928) is 
no. 103, pp. 21—24, where the case of Grus is very ably put 
forward. This I regard as quite beyond the mark, and is one of 
44 special pleading.' 5 

IV 
PREFACE. 
I disagree entirely with this ruling, as I consider Grus an 
absolute synonym of Psophia Linn£. 
I quite agree with Allen, in * American Museum of Natural 
History,’ vol. xxiii. p. 313, April 15th, 1907, as I said in the 
Novit. Zoolog. vol. xvii. p. 502, Dec. 1910. Having read the 
Opinion, and again gone into the matter, I consider that later 
authorities will also agree with Allen. 
If we allow “ special pleading,” a very big field is opened, 
and some of the excellent work done by the Commission will 
have to be re-done. 
GREGORY M. MATHEWS. 
Mead way, St. Cross, Winchester. 
May 20th, 1930.

(extinct).

June 24th). Type (by monotypy): Sitta formosa Blyth. Re¬ 
places Dendrophila Swainson, Class. Birds, vol. ii. p. 318, June 
1837. Type (D. Jlavipes) not Dendrophilus Leach, Zool.’ Misc. 
vol. iii. p. 171, 1817, or Dendrophila Hodgson, April, 1837.

* It may be well to record that Dr. Alexander Wetmore in 1923 saw a 
thriving colony of a thousand or moro individuals of the domestic Canary ( Serinus 
canarius canarius (L.), which had been released on Midway Island, about the 
Cable Station, and wore completely acclimatized and had been breeding for 
a number of years.

APPENDIX. 
P. 4. Casuarius bicarunculatus intermedius Rothschild.

probably the two large islands between Kobroon and 
Trangan. 
Distr. — Aru Islands. 
P. 7. Casuarius rogersi Rothschild.

p. 87, April 24th, 1928 : probably from one of the more 
isolated coastal ranges of Geelvink Bay, North-West New 
Guinea. 
Distr . — New Guinea (North-West). 
P. 9. Add as synonym of patagonica Miller : 
Aptenodytes maxima Molina, (Gio Ignazio) Saggio Sulla Storia 
Naturale del Chili, 2nd ed. p. 201, 1810 : substitute name 
for A. patagonica Lath. = Miller. 
P. 13. Megapodius reinwardt yorki Math. 
Megapodius reinwardt yorki , Mathews, Bull. Brit. Orn. Club, 
vol. 1. p. 11, October 31st, 1929 : Cedar Bay, North Queens¬ 
land. 
Distr . — North Queensland (Cape York to Cairns). 
P. 21. Tumix rufilata Wallace and Turnix powelli Guillemard 
are probably subspecies of Turnix [ juvaniea= ] javanica 
Rafinesque, Princ. Fondarn. de Somiologie, page 2 of cover, 
after June 3rd, 1814, for the bird described, Bull, des 
Sciences, par la Societe Philomatique, ser iii. nos. 67-68, 
1803: Java (cf. Richmond, Auk, 1909, p. 256). 
P. 21. Use Tur nix maculosa melanotus (Gould) 
for the Australian subspecies. 
P. 22. For Turnix maculosa rufescens Wallace use : 
Turnix maculosa maculosa (Tcmminck). (22-546.) 
Hcmipodius maculosus Temminck, Pig. et. Gall. vol. iii. p. 631, 
1815: Nouvelle Ilollande, error= Timor (type in Paris 
Mus.; Col. Baudin). 
Turnix maculatus Vieillot, Nouv. Diet. d’Hist. Nat. vol. xxxv. p. 47, 
Dec. 1819, for the same bird.

APPENDIX. 
913 
Spiloglaux ocellata (Bp.). San Cristobal Owl. 
Athene ocellata Bonaparte, Consp. Gen. Av. vol. i. p. 42, June, 
1850: Occania=San Cristobal Island, ex Hombron et 
Jacquinot. MS.; Pucheran, Voy. Pole Sud, Zool. vol. iii. 
p. 51, pi. 3. fig. 2, Oct. 10th, 1853 : Chili. South America, 
error=San Cristobal Island. 
Spiloglaux roseoaxil'laris Hartert, Amer. Mus. Nov. no. 3G4, p. 6, 
July 29th, 1929 : Sail Cristobal Island, Solomon Islands. 
Distr .— San Cristobal Island, Solomon Islands. 
I have compared Hartert ’s bird with the plate of Athene 
ocellata Bp. figured in the Atlas of the P61e Sud, pi. 3. fig. 2, 
and consider it the same species. On this same plate is 
figured Bonaparte’s type of jacquinoti from St. George 
Island^ near Ysabel Island, Solomon Islands. 
Pucheran gave the locality of ocellata as Chili; this was cor¬ 
rected by Bonaparte to Oceania. The measurements of 
this bird as given by Pucheran are larger than those given 
by Hartert:— 
Pucheran, tail 118 mm. Hartert, tail 80 
„ bill 29 „ „ bill 24*4 
„ tarsus 35 „ „ tarsus 32*7 
As ocellata is the only Owl from this locality with a white 
throat, I must use this name, more especially as the bird 
agrees well with the type-plate. Bonaparte’s jacquinoti 
agrees as well with the type-figure on the same plate as 
roseoaxillaris does with the type-figure of ocellata. They 
both came from the Solomon Islands. 
273. Spiloglaux jacquinoti jacquinoti (Bp.). 
Saint George Island Owl.
